articles.title: Component Party: A Rosetta Stone of UI Libraries
articles.description: A long-standing comparison of many different frameworks (like React, Vue, Svelte, Angular, Qwik, Solid.js, etc.) by way of simple code snippets to perform various tasks. Now including Svelte 5 and Angular 17/Renaissance.
articles.author: Mathieu Schimmerling

articles.title: Will We Care About Frameworks in the Future?
articles.description: Paul wonders if the increasing use of LLMs and agents in software development will lead to a reduction in the need for new frameworks and extra developer-focused abstractions.
articles.author: Paul Kinlan

articles.title: The vlt Package Manager and Serverless Registry
articles.description: A very experienced team, including npm creator Isaac Schlueter, launched Vlt to ‚Äòbuild the future‚Äô of JavaScript package management. The first results have appeared in the shape of the vlt client (which can replace npm), as well as a serverless package registry you can self host to serve up your own packages.
articles.author: Clarke, Adorno, Schlueter, and Karrys

articles.title: TypeScript 5.7 Release Candidate
articles.description: The popular typed JS superset adds support for ES2024 as a target, can report errors when variables aren't initialized, adds path rewriting for relative paths, and can use Node‚Äôs compile caching to save on parsing work. The final release is expected in a week or two.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: JavaScript Import Attributes (ES2025) Explained
articles.description: Import Attributes (now at stage 4 at TC39 and already supported in some runtimes) add a way to supply useful metadata about modules you‚Äôre importing.
articles.author: Trevor I. Lasn

articles.title: Creating an ASCII Shader Using OGL
articles.description: An incredibly cool effect demonstrated in a great tutorial on getting started with shaders and using OGL, a lightweight WebGL library.
articles.author: Andrico Karoulla

articles.title: How a BBC Navigation Bar Component Broke Depending on Which External Monitor It Was On
articles.description: A look at an interesting bug related to external monitor positioning. The lesson is that ‚Äúbrowsers have an interoperability issue in how they represent screen coordinates in multi-monitor setups‚Äù.
articles.author: Josh Tumath

articles.title: How to Set Up Next.js 15 for Production in 2024
articles.description: Share in this author‚Äôs experience in scaling up Next.js apps to over 100k monthly active users and millions of monthly visitors.
articles.author: Jan Hesters (ReactSquad)

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†From Next.js to htmx: A Real World Example
articles.description: An interesting case study explained in a 50-minute screencast: ‚ÄúReplacing my components with the equivalent HTML elements powered by htmx wasn‚Äôt exactly an easy task, but one that was worth the time.‚Äù
articles.author: Pouria Ezzati

articles.title: Lexical 0.20: An Easy-to-Extend Text Editor Framework from Meta
articles.description: A text editor framework built by Meta with extensibility, accessibility, and cross platform support in mind (there‚Äôs even a Swift variant for iOS). There‚Äôs a live playground if you want to give it a try. React support is first class, but it can be adapted to work elsewhere (as with svelte-lexical).
articles.author: Meta / Facebook

articles.title: Storybook 8.4 Released
articles.description: A minor release for the powerful frontend component workshop but ‚Äúone of our most feature-packed minor releases‚Äù with one click component testing, Svelte 5 support, and React Native Storybook 8.
articles.author: Michael Shilman

articles.title: üóìÔ∏è¬†Schedule-X 2.5: Material Design Calendar and Date Picker
articles.description: Available in the form of React/Preact, Vue, Svelte, Angular, or plain JS components. Open source but with a premium version with extra features. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Tom √ñsterlund

articles.title: üéµ¬†music-metadata: Stream and File-Based Music Metadata Parser
articles.description: Supporting formats like MP3, FLAC, Ogg, WAV, WMA, AAC and AIFF, this library extracts metadata like ID3v1 and iTunes tags for processing however you want. Yes, it even works in the browser.
articles.author: Borewit

articles.title: Micromark 4.0.1: A Small Compliant Markdown Parser
articles.description: 100% compliance with the CommonMark standard, supports extensions (such as for GitHub Flavored Markdown), and full test coverage.
articles.author: Titus Wormer

articles.title: jsep 1.4: JavaScript Expression Parser
articles.description: ‚ÄúThink of jsep as a tool to parse the kinds of expressions that would be written in individual Excel cells.‚Äù
articles.author: Stephen Oney

articles.description: ü§ñ Microsoft has introduced Copilot Edits in VS Code ‚Äì it provides a way to work across multiple files in a project at once.
Jawsm is an early-stage, experimental JavaScript to WebAssembly compiler (akin to Porffor) but that aims to use the most advanced WASM features off the bat, such as WasmGC and exception handling.
üíú CSS now has an official logo!
Expo SDK 52 ‚Äì Toolset for building modern React Native apps, now supporting React Native 0.76 and the New Architecture.
Node.js v18.20.5 (LTS) ‚Äì Lots of dependency updates and now import attributes and JSON modules are marked stable.
No announcement, but it looks like Ember 6.0 is about to land.
Node.js v23.2.0 (Current), pnpm 9.13, Parcel 2.13.0

articles.title: Beautiful Focus Outlines
articles.description: Thomas notes that focus outlines are often seen as a purely technical requirement, but suggests we should treat them as essential design elements that can help create ‚Äúinterfaces that are both beautiful and inclusive‚Äù, noting how they are fundamental to an accessible web. Also looks at a multi-colored striped approach, and a proposed native way to handling just that. Plenty of good examples here.
articles.author: Thomas G√ºnther

articles.title: A Recap of Google's Web AI Summit 2024
articles.description: Google recently held a summit specifically about the use of machine learning models directly in the browser, specifically by developers creating new, rich experiences for users. It‚Äôs interesting to see how things are progressing here and you can watch some of the talks on YouTube.
articles.author: Jason Mayes (Google)

articles.title: An Official Logo for CSS
articles.description: After hundreds of votes, CSS now has its own logo, moving beyond the shield and number combo of the CSS 3 era. We‚Äôve got a main rebeccapurple version (pictured), along with a dark and light version.
articles.author: CSS-Next Community Group

articles.title: New CSS That Can Actually Be Used in 2024
articles.description: Yep, the amount of CSS changes and additions in the last two to four years has been staggering, as such this page (published earlier this year) is a good cheatsheet reminder, of sorts, for newer things we can do with CSS.
articles.author: Thomasorus

articles.title: How a BBC Navigation Bar Component Broke Depending on Which External Monitor It Was On
articles.description: Some interesting spelunking into a very odd little bug (with a fairly simple fix) related to external monitor positioning. The lesson being that ‚Äúbrowsers have an interoperability issue in how they represent screen coordinates in multi-monitor set ups‚Äù ‚Äî a quirk you likely won't run into much, but worth knowing about.
articles.author: Josh Tumath

articles.title: Fluid Everything Else
articles.description: An exploration of how we can apply the concept of 'fluid typography' to realize layouts that change with the size of a parent container, without the user noticing any transition.
articles.author: Richard Hubbard

articles.title: (Up-) Scoped Scroll Timelines
articles.description: Chris continues his exploration of just what can be done with scroll-driven animations, this time quickly looking at how we can get elements on a page to ‚Äòlisten‚Äô to a scroll (or view) timeline of a totally different element.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: How to Create an Organic Text Distortion Effect with Infinite¬†Scrolling
articles.description: Here‚Äôs a live demo of this striking, if disorienting, effect.
articles.author: Jorge Toloza

articles.title: Pagefind: Add a Search Feature to Your Static Sites
articles.description: A fully static search library that aims to perform well on even large sites, while using as little of your users‚Äô bandwidth as possible, and without hosting any infrastructure (you can use it with any static site generation system). Version 1.2.0 landed last week.
articles.author: CloudCannon

articles.title: Action Table: A Native HTML Web Component for Adding Sorting/Filtering Functionality to Tables
articles.description: Uses custom styles that you can override for branding and there's a rather epic demo with examples to fiddle around with including a 1000-row paginated table to give you an idea of its performance. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Colin Fahrion

articles.title: Storybook 8.4 Released
articles.description: The popular frontend component workshop gets a minor release but it‚Äôs ‚Äúone of our most feature-packed minor releases ever‚Äù with one click component testing, Svelte 5 support, React Native Storybook 8, and other niceties.
articles.author: Michael Shilman

articles.title: üó∫Ô∏è¬†Tiny Static Map: A Simple Map Rendering Element
articles.description: A very small library for putting a static map onto a page centered on a specific lat/long of your choice. It uses OpenStreetMap. Note the GPL 3 license, however.
articles.author: Bob Something

articles.title: ska-tailwind-editor: Edit Tailwind HTML As WordPress Blocks
articles.description: This is an online editor that looks like the WordPress block editor with its various options, except this one allows you to edit the HTML using Tailwind classes.
articles.author: Sinu Koduleheabi
